# Preventing & Solving Problems

## A Preface

-   Debugging is programming.
    -   It's not extra; it's essential.
-   Programming depends on collaboration.
    -   Asking for help is not cheating!
-   Questions \> Answers
    -   Get the basics down, then get everything else you need when you need it.
-   Troubleshooting includes debugging, *among other things*.
    -   These skills translate beyond fixing code.
    -   Please stop telling me that "in programming it's called debugging."

## The Myth of the "Programmer"

::::: columns
::: {.column width="60%"}
-   Programmers are geniuses who have a sacred knowledge. 
-   The debugging coders do is a highly specialized skill.
-   If you're debugging, you did something wrong.
-   Programming requires mastery of a programming language.
-   You can recognize an expert programmer by their abundant knowledge of the language.
    -   or their wardrobe of unwashed hoodies meticulously curated to signal how much they don't care about anything but code
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}

![](../images/comics-memes/silicon-2.jpg)

:::
:::::

## The Reality of Getting Shit Done

::: row

::: col-7

-   Debugging is not extra – it's the majority of the process.
-   Debugging is one application of more generalizable problem-solving skills.
-   Programming depends on collaboration.
-   Once you "master" the foundations, you learn the rest by just going for it.
-   You can recognize an expert programmer by their ability to find solutions.
    -   [*They might also wear gross hoodies, but don't we all from time to time?*]{style="font-size: .8em"}
    
:::

::: col-5

![](../images/comics-memes/silicon-1.jpg)

:::
:::

::: {.callout-tip .bigger}
## Questions \> Answers

Knowing how to ask the right questions to solve problems and learn independently is legitimately, indisputably more valuable than the party trick of recalling lots of functions and language-specific processes.
:::

::: notes
-   **Debugging is not extra – it's essential**
    -   80% of programming time is spent debugging <!-- there's got to be a cartoon for this -->
-   **Troubleshooting includes debugging, *among other things*.**
    -   These skills translate beyond fixing code.
    -   Please stop telling me that "in programming it's called debugging."
-   **Programming depends on collaboration**
    -   Asking for help is not cheating!
    -   Programming knowledge is freely **distributed and shared**
-   **Questions \> Answers**
    -   Get the basics down, then get everything else you need when you need it.
-   **Master the foundations and then just go for it**
:::

## ![](../images/icons/intelligible.png){style="height: 1em; vertical-align: middle; margin-right: 0.4em;"} Intelligible Code: Commenting 

::: {.d-flex style="gap: 0.4em; margin-bottom: 2em; margin-top: -1em; font-size: 0.7em;"}

[Standardized]{style="background-color: #ddd; color: #666; padding: 0.2em 0.6em; border-radius: 3px;"}
[**Intelligible**]{style="background-color: #8B1A1A; color: white; padding: 0.2em 0.6em; border-radius: 3px;"}

::: row

::: col-7

1.  Comments should not duplicate code
2.  Good comments do not excuse unclear code
3.  If you can't write a clear comment, there may be a problem with the code
4.  Comments should dispel confusion, not cause it
5.  Explain unidiomatic code in comments
6.  Provide links to the original source of copied code
7.  Include links to external references where helpful
8.  Add comments when fixing bugs
9.  Use comments to mark incomplete implementations

:::

## ![](../images/icons/consistency.png){style="height: 1em; vertical-align: middle; margin-right: 0.4em;"} Maintainable Code: Function Lifecycles

<table class="compact" style="width: 80%;">

</tr>
</table>


::: notes
If you don't see a lifecycles tag in the CRAN documentation, that means it's stable.\

**Experimental**

-   In development ("beta")
-   May or may not reach stable
-   Can be very helpful for a specific use-case
-   Use with caution
-   Note use in comments in case updates produce errors or collaborators only use stable functions

**Stable**

-   Default stage
-   Functional, current, maintained
-   **Prioritize these!**

**Superseded**

-   Still supported
-   Better (stable) alternative exists
-   Will not be updated, but will not go away
-   Safe to use, but prioritize recommended replacements

**Deprecated**

-   Works now but not for long
-   Use only as a temporary last resort
-   Prioritize recommended replacement
:::

- Incomplete datasets will get more data
- "Complete" datasets may eliminate some data
- Variables may need to be combined, anonymized, mutated, etc.
:::

::: {.callout-tip .large icon=false style="font-size: 1.1em;"}
### [⇆  How similar are your data to other data?]{style="padding-left:1em;"}

- Will you (or anyone else) conduct a follow-up or replication?
- Do you already know there were problems in data collection that will mean new data format when fixed next time?
- Do other researchers in your area use similar data collection methods but different organization methods?

## ![](../images/icons/consistency.png){style="height: 1em; vertical-align: middle; margin-right: 0.4em;"} Caveat: Non-evil Copy/Paste

::: {.d-flex style="gap: 0.4em; margin-bottom: 2em; margin-top: -1em; font-size: 0.7em;"}

[Standardized]{style="background-color: #ddd; color: #666; padding: 0.2em 0.6em; border-radius: 3px;"}
[Intelligible]{style="background-color: #ddd; color: #666; padding: 0.2em 0.6em; border-radius: 3px;"} 
[**Maintainable**]{style="background-color: #8B1A1A; color: white; padding: 0.2em 0.6em; border-radius: 3px;"}
[Contextualized]{style="background-color: #ddd; color: #666; padding: 0.2em 0.6em; border-radius: 3px;"}

:::

When *should* you copy and paste?

-   [Forking]{.keyword}: purposefully creating variants for exploration
-   [Templates]{.keyword}: starting points for new projects
-   [Debugging]{.keyword}: temporary workarounds to identify specific problems
-   ["Clone and own"]{.keyword}: adapt foundational code to new contexts

::: notes
copy-and-paste coding is bad, but there's nothing wrong with copying and pasting code in principle.
When should you copy and paste?

purposefully creating variants for exploration
don't reinvent the wheel for the sake of originality
temporary workarounds
copy foundational code and adapt to specific contexts

:::

### Absolute vs. Relative Paths

```{.r code-line-numbers="|1-2|4-5|7-8"}
## Only works on my computer no matter what
absolute_path <- "Users/Natalie/repos/d2mr/example-repo/images/barplot.jpg"

# Works on your machine if you clone it to this location on your computer
mixed_path <- "~/repos/d2mr/example-repo/images/barplot.jpg"

# Works when you clone the repo anywhere
relative_path <- "/images/barplot.jpg"

```


## ![](../images/icons/consistency.png){style="height: 1em; vertical-align: middle; margin-right: 0.4em;"} Maintainable Code: Abstraction

::: {.d-flex style="gap: 0.4em; margin-bottom: 2em; margin-top: -1em; font-size: 0.7em;"}

[Standardized]{style="background-color: #ddd; color: #666; padding: 0.2em 0.6em; border-radius: 3px;"}
[Intelligible]{style="background-color: #ddd; color: #666; padding: 0.2em 0.6em; border-radius: 3px;"} 
[**Maintainable**]{style="background-color: #8B1A1A; color: white; padding: 0.2em 0.6em; border-radius: 3px;"}
[Contextualized]{style="background-color: #ddd; color: #666; padding: 0.2em 0.6em; border-radius: 3px;"}

:::

### Hard-coded vs. Dynamic Variables

```{.r code-line-numbers="|1-2|4-7|9-13"}
# Always equals 3
my_mean <- (2 + 4)/2

# Output will change to reflect changes to 2 input variables
x <- 2; y <- 4 # or...
x <- 3; y <- 10
the_mean <- (x + y)/2

# Output will change no matter how many input numerals are averaged
number_list <- c(2,3) # or...
number_list <- 2:8 # or...
number_list <- c(1,2,8,100)
a_mean <- sum(number_list)/length(number_list)

```


::: notes
Abstracted (relative) paths and variables are more durable than hard-coded (absolute) ones
:::

## ![](../images/icons/flexible.png){style="height: 1em; vertical-align: middle; margin-right: 0.4em;"} Contextualized Code: Community Standards

::: {.d-flex style="gap: 0.4em; margin-bottom: 2em; margin-top: -1em; font-size: 0.7em;"}

[Standardized]{style="background-color: #ddd; color: #666; padding: 0.2em 0.6em; border-radius: 3px;"}

[**Contextualized**]{style="background-color: #8B1A1A; color: white; padding: 0.2em 0.6em; border-radius: 3px;"}

:::

Know your community and follow its conventions.

- [R Conventions](https://bookdown.org/yih_huynh/Guide-to-R-Book/r-conventions.html) (for everyone)
- [R Developer Community Culture](https://journal.r-project.org/articles/RJ-2021-110/)
- Find your communities and respect their rules.
    - Gatekeep-y? Admittedly, yes, but that's not the goal
    - Facilitate communication, collaboration, and shared ownership

::: notes
Find your communities (plural) and do your best to respect their rules. This isn’t so much about gatekeeping and in-grouping (though it can certainty feel that way). It’s more about promoting collaboration. When everyone talks about their work in a similar way – whether it’s using the same style guide, preferring certain plots for certain analyses, opting for one package or another, formatting example random data, whatever – it’s much easier to work in forked repos, respond to crowd-sourced questions, understand others’ presentations, and just generally work together toward shared intentions.

:::

The visual editor generates a lot of hidden code and formatting that makes your .qmd files difficult to read, troubleshoot, and maintain. This is really critical if you ever want to really fine-tune your formatting or layout. Switching into the visual editor can just break everything without an easy undo to restore what was working.


-   do 1 and only 1 thing
-   have informative & unique names 
-   specify whether to run and what to display when knit
-   be placed at the point they are needed/referenced
-   be (relatively) short – source longer scripts if necessary


 
 
:::

## Chunk Names

Name your chunks to minimize human error. They should be:

- Unique
- Informative
    - `fig-gesture-stacked-bar` not `gesture-graph`
- Conventional (conservative + correct)
    - Avoid: special characters, spaces, underscores
    - Prefer: letters, hyphens, numerals
    
::: {.callout-warning .bigger .fragment}

### 1 Chunk 1 Thing

*Unique* and *informative* chunk names depend on each chunk doing *1 and only 1 thing.* Can you explain what the point of the chunk is in 1-3 words? If not, you've probably got 1 chunk doing too many things.

:::

::: notes

- Conventional (conservative + correct)
    - R variables cannot start with a numeral, so even though chunk names legally can, it's better to avoid it. 
    - Don't use underscores or spaces! Even if they "work," they won't *work* work. They'll break in things that can otherwise understand quarto documents but aren't quarto.
    
    1 Chunk ➝ 1 Thing

 Even if you are creating multiple closely related figures (or tables), best practice is to have each figure actually generate (i.e., knit) from its own chunk.
 In the spirit of minimal copy/paste + 1 thing per chunk, consider a figure setup chunk where the "1 thing" it does is lay out all the properties (themes, layers, data filtering, etc.) that are shared by the figures to follow
    
:::

<h3 style="margin-top:0em">Mutating joins</h3>

#### Description

Mutating joins add columns from y to x, matching observations based on the keys. There are four mutating joins: the inner join, and the three outer joins.

*Inner join*
An inner_join() only keeps observations from x that have a matching key in y.

*[...text omitted...]{style="color: #999"}*

#### Usage

```{.r}
inner_join(
  x,
  y,
  by = NULL,
  copy = FALSE,
  suffix = c(".x", ".y"),
  ...,
  keep = NULL
)

left_join(
  x,
  y,
  by = NULL,
  copy = FALSE,
  suffix = c(".x", ".y"),
  ...,
  keep = NULL
)
```

## Error messages

Errors starting with these phrases are super common and have predictable causes:

-   `could not find function`: the function's package is not loaded (or more commonly, typos)
-   `Error in if`: non-logical data or missing values passed to R's `if` conditional statement
-  ` Error in eval`: references to objects that don't exist
-   `cannot open`: attempts to read a file that doesn't exist or can't be accessed
-   `no applicable method`: using an object-oriented function on a data type it doesn't support
-   `subscript out of bounds`: trying to access an element or dimension that doesn't exist
-   `package errors`: R cannot install or load a package due to missing dependencies or conflicts

## Line-by-Line Debugging

There is a problem, but *where* is the problem?

-   Break down code into smaller pieces and run them one line at a time.
-   Debug *outside* a code "container" by hardcoding values
    -   loops, functions, pipelines
-   Use [RStudio's debugging tools](https://support.posit.co/hc/en-us/articles/205612627-Debugging-with-the-RStudio-IDE)

::: {.callout-tip .fragment}

### RStudio Debugging Shortcut

-   Run current line or selected code: `Cmd + Return`
-   Run current chunk: `Cmd + Option + C`
-   Run all: `Shift + Cmd + Return`

*Windows: Cmd=Ctrl, Option=Alt, Return=Enter*

:::



::: notes

If you get an error message, it will tell you exactly where things went wrong.
Otherwise, you do line-by-line.

What if the code runs just fine, but doesn't produce the expected output?

Break down code into smaller pieces and run them in order
l-b-l debug outside the loop/function/pipe sequence by "hard-coding" the arguments that will eventually rely on changeable input
Tips for line-by-line debugging in RStudio

:::

# Asking for help

## Start Strong

-   []{.bi-exclamation-octagon-fill} Get what you can from error messages. 
-   []{.bi-pin-map-fill} Identify the problem points as precisely as possible.
-   []{.bi-hourglass-split} Do your best to figure it out yourself.

::: notes

Ask for help! Yay asking for help! BUT YOU STILL NEED TO TRY TO FIGURE IT OUT YOURSELF FIRST. You'll know what to look for and how to ask the right questions if you've already done that work. Also people will want to know what steps you've already tried so their answers will be useful.

:::

## Minimally Reproducible Examples

-   **Minimal:** only the code necessary to reproduce the problem
-   **Reproducible:** includes any data or package dependencies
-   **Example:** illustrates the problem clearly


::: {.callout-tip .large .fragment}


### MRE Ingredients

[*StackOverflow*](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5963269/how-to-make-a-great-r-reproducible-example/5963610)

::: nonincremental
1. The minimal and sufficient dataset used (usually not your actual data! better to use built-in data like iris or cars; run `data()` for more).
2. Minimal and sufficient runnable code
3. Necessary session and OS info, including loaded libraries and seed if used.
:::

:::

## Ask AI

-   [Use GitHub Copilot in RStudio](https://docs.posit.co/ide/user/ide/guide/tools/copilot.html)
-   Yes, you can and should use AI. Just be smart about it.
-   AI is your overconfident and entirely uninvested collaborator.
-   As a beginner programmer:
    -   DO use AI as a debugging resource
    -   DO use AI to explain code
    -   DON'T use AI to generate code you can't write yourself
    -   DON'T give it the same confidence it gives itself

::: notes

AI is great and a gamechanger for programming, but it cannot replace knowledge of how the code actually works. Asking AI to produce anything but the simplest code is going to produce errors. They are often SUPER EASY to fix, but you'll need to know how to recognize what's going on. You need to know how it's supposed to work even if you didn't generate it all yourself.

Basically think of chatGPT as a collaborator. They can do a ton, but if this project is ultimately your responsibility, you need to have the foundations to work WITH it (and know how and when to give up and do it yourself when the AI is totally fucked).
